oai_dc:dc.dc:description: <jats:p>We address the problem of spontaneous hybridization between an exotic species<jats:italic>Pinus mugo</jats:italic>and the native/local<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>at the seaside spit of Kursiu Nerija in Lithuania. The objective was to identify spontaneous hybrids between<jats:italic>P. mugo</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>based on morphology traits among the individuals naturally regenerating at the seaside spit. The field inventory was carried out over the entire Lithuanian part of the spit, and 200 individuals morphologically intermediate between<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>P. mugo</jats:italic>were identified. Based on a weighted trait index, the intermediate individuals were grouped into two groups, one morphologically close to<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>and another close to<jats:italic>P. mugo</jats:italic>. The needle micromorphological traits of the putative hybrids were of intermediate values between<jats:italic>P. mugo</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>. The results provide a strong evidence of spontaneous hybridization between<jats:italic>P. mugo</jats:italic>and<jats:italic>P. sylvestris</jats:italic>in Lithuanian seaside spit of Kursiu Nerija.</jats:p>
